duck: Present is a time that is neither past nor future.

milestones: Maria Menounos will present the 2006 Eurovision Song Contest
Michelle Obama, Hillary Clinton present 2012 International Women of Courage Awards
Militants to present evidence Malacanang sanctioned killings
Google's YouTube to present its best video awards
Brazilian Vote Buying parliamentary commission present first joint preliminary report
New Zealand MP to be present at state funeral of Gerald Ford

Chris Moyles announces departure from BBC Radio 1 breakfast show
2010 BRIT Awards highlights

Sudan
Chris Moyles departs from BBC Radio 1 breakfast show
Jonathan Ross departs from BBC

New York City considers stricter regulations on trans fat

wiki.text:
and future.]] The 'present' (or 'now') is the time that is associated with the
 events perceived directly and in the first time,<ref>Hegeler, E. C., & Carus,
 P. (1890). [http://books.google.com/books?id=3KoLAAAAIAAJ The Monist]. La
 Salle, Ill. [etc.]: Published by Open Court for the Hegeler Institute. page
 443.</ref> not as a recollection (perceived more than once) or a speculation
 (predicted, hypothesis, uncertain). It is a period of time between the past and
 the future, and can vary in meaning from being an instant to a day or longer.
 In radiocarbon dating, the "present" is defined as AD 1950.

It is sometimes represented as a hyperplane in space-time,<ref>Sattig, T.
(2006). [http://books.google.com/books?id=qYNv2zpHOmwC The language and reality
of time]. Oxford: Clarendon Press. Page 37.</ref> typically called "now",
although modern physics demonstrates that such a hyperplane can not be defined
uniquely for observers in relative motion. The present may also be viewed as a
duration (see [[specious present]]).<ref name="JamesW">James, W. (1893).
[http://books.google.com/books?id=JLcAAAAAMAAJ The principles of psychology].
New York: H. Holt and Company. Page 609.</ref><ref>Hodder, A. (1901). The
adversaries of the sceptic; or, The specious present, a new inquiry into human
knowledge. [http://books.google.com/books?id=uZ5RAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA36&source=gbs_t-
oc_r&cad=0_0 Chapter II, The Specious Present]. London: S. Sonnenschein &.
Pages 36 - 56.</ref>
wiki.title: present
